case_data.name: Sacred Heart of Jesus Parish, Grand Rapids v. Nessel
case_data.plaintiff_description: A religious organization, its school, and multiple private plaintiffs who are members of the religious organization.
case_data.summary:
This is a case about whether Michigan’s Elliot-Larsen Civil Rights Act, which, in 2022, the Michigan Supreme Court interpreted to prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity, unconstitutionally infringed on religious liberty.  On December 22, 2022, Sacred Heart of Jesus Parish filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Michigan. Sacred Heart, alongside its school, Sacred Heart Academy, and several individual Sacred Heart members (collectively “Sacred Heart”), sued the Michigan Attorney General, Department of Civil Rights, and Civil Rights Commission under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 alleging violations of their First and Fourteenth Amendment rights. Sacred Heart claimed that application of the Elliott-Larsen Civil Rights Act to prohibit sexual orientation and gender identity discrimination in employment, education, and public accommodation interfered with its ability to practice its Catholic beliefs. In particular, Sacred Heart alleged that it could not at once comply with the Act’s prohibitions on discrimination and limit enrollment, hiring, and/or use of space (including bathrooms) to form an “intentional Catholic community” in line with Catholic values.   Therefore, Sacred Heart claimed that the Act violated its free speech and free religious exercise rights as well as associational and parental rights. Represented by the Alliance Defending Freedom, Sacred Heart sought declaratory relief, injunctive relief, and costs and attorneys’ fees. Also on December 22, 2022, Sacred Heart filed a motion for a preliminary injunction to enjoin the state from enforcing the expanded Act against them.

The case was first assigned to District Court Judge Robert J. Jonker and then reassigned to District Court Judge Jane M. Beckering and Magistrate Judge Phillip J. Green.  As of January 2023, the case is ongoing and the preliminary injunction motion remains pending.
case_data.summary_short: In December 2022, a Grand Rapids Parish sued the state of Michigan, claiming that Michigan's recent expansion of the Elliot-Larsen Civil Rights Act to protect LGBTQ people unconstitutionally infringed on its ability to practice its Catholic beliefs. The plaintiff, Sacred Heart of Jesus Parish, filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Michigan. Sacred Heart of Jesus Parish moved for a preliminary injunction, but it remains to be seen how District Court Judge Jane M. Beckering and Magistrate Judge Phillip J. Green will rule on this motion. This case is in its early stages and will be updated on the Clearinghouse as more information becomes available.

Introduction 
Sacred Heart of Jesus Parish has been serving the spiritual needs of the 
Grand Rapids community for more than a century. In all its years of ministry, 
Sacred Heart has never had a problem operating consistent with both the teachings

and penal code to include sexual orientation and gender identity, without providing

practicing the Catholic faith or close its doors forever.  
To comply with Michiganโs re-understood laws, Sacred Heart Parish and its

violates Sacred Heartโs free speech and free exercise rights. Rather than defy 
Catholic doctrine in these ways, Sacred Heart would shut down.

parental and free exercise rights of its families are also implicated. Parents have 
explicitly opted out of public schools in favor of sending their children to Sacred 
Heart for an authentic Catholic education where their children would never be 
exposed to harmful ideas and ideologies that contradict the Catholic faith. When 
Michigan prevents Sacred Heart from operating its school consistent with its 
Catholic beliefs, it also necessarily violates the fundamental parental and free 
exercise rights of Sacred Heart families.
